home.text1: UNLOCK YOUR FULL POTENTIAL & THRIVE IN BUSINESS
home.text2: Our comprehensive test and insightful PDF report will empower you to reach new heights in your entrepreneurial journey

toast.testStartedMessage: Test has been started. All the best.
toast.acceptTermsMessage: Please accept our terms and condition to continue

instruction.welcomeMessage: Welcome to the test! This test contains 26 questions, and for each question, you'll have four options to choose from.
instructionList: Ensure you are in a quiet environment to concentrate on the test.
Read each question carefully and choose the best option.
You can change an option only until you submit the test.
There is no time limit, so take your time and do your best!
After clicking the "Start Test" button, full-screen mode will be enabled.
This test is designed to assess your knowledge and skills in various areas.
Please answer each question to the best of your ability.
instruction.noteMessage: If you accidentally exit full-screen mode during the test, you can click the "Go Full Screen" button again to re-enable it.

disclaimer.heading: Disclaimer
disclaimer.websiteInfo: This website, Udyam Uplift, provides psychometric tests and related content for informational purposes only. The information and reports generated by our services are curated by experts to depict personality traits with a high degree of accuracy. However, it is important to note that no personality assessment tool can guarantee 100% accuracy.
disclaimer.userResponsibilitiesText: Users are encouraged to take the psychometric tests on their own and provide truthful responses. The accuracy of the results is greatly dependent on the honesty and accuracy of user input. Udyam Uplift is not responsible for any decisions or actions taken based on the information provided on this website.
disclaimer.legalProtectionText: This disclaimer is provided for legal protection and to inform users about the limitations of our services. Udyam Uplift is not responsible for any decisions or actions taken based on the information provided on this website.
disclaimer.contactInfoPlaceholder: If you have any questions or concerns regarding this disclaimer or our services, please contact us at

privacyPolicy.heading: Privacy Policy
privacyPolicy.informationTypesHeader: We collect various types of personal information, including but not limited to:
privacyPolicy.name: Name:
privacyPolicy.nameDescription: We collect your name to personalize your experience on our platform.
privacyPolicy.emailAddressDescription: We collect your email address for communication and account-related notifications.
privacyPolicy.testResponsesDescription: We collect your responses to psychometric tests to provide you with personalized insights.
privacyPolicy.userInputsDescription: We gather information provided by you during interactions on our platform.
privacyPolicy.activitiesOnWebsiteDescription: We track your activities on our website for analytics and personalization.
privacyPolicy.ipAddressesDescription: We collect IP addresses for security and location-based services.
privacyPolicy.cookiesDescription: We use cookies to enhance your experience and offer personalized content.
privacyPolicy.howWeCollectInfoDescription: We collect information through registration forms when users create accounts on our website. This information helps us create your user account and provide you with personalized content and services.
privacyPolicy.howWeUseInfoDescription: We use the collected information to create and personalize user accounts. This allows us to offer a tailored experience, including customized test results and recommendations.
privacyPolicy.sharingOfInfoDescription: We do not share user data with third parties. Your information is kept confidential and used only for providing services on our platform.
privacyPolicy.cookiesAndTrackingDescription: We use cookies for personalization purposes. Cookies help us enhance your experience by remembering your preferences and providing personalized content.
privacyPolicy.securityDescription: We take data security seriously. We protect user data using encryption and secure servers to ensure your information is safe and confidential.
privacyPolicy.userRightsDescription: Users have the right to access their data. If you have any questions or concerns about your data, please contact us at
privacyPolicy.lastUpdated: This Privacy Policy was last updated on 25/09/2023.
privacyPolicy.contactUs: If you have any questions or concerns, please contact us at

question.questionText: Regarding the matter of facilitating Group Discussions and selecting between smaller groups versus larger groups:
options: I find larger groups more comforting, as they let me follow the majority's ideas.
Both small and large groups have their merits, as everyone has something valuable to contribute.
Smaller groups may lead to better decisions since everyone has the chance to express their opinions.
I can uphold my individuality in any group size, but larger groups may cause biased outcomes.

question.questionText: When everyone agrees with a single person's choice, I find it challenging to express a contrasting view because:
options: It's nice to receive approval from our group by adhering to a unanimous decision.
Disagreeing might appear impolite. I could discuss my concerns individually without disrupting the group.
I believe everyone considers the best course of action, and it's unlikely that all of them are incorrect simultaneously.
I don't hesitate to share my thoughts, even if it means standing apart.

question.questionText: Recently, some of my colleagues at office joined a CSR activity club where they plant trees and keep a track of their well being. They have gained a lot of popularity because of this. I believe I will also enrol my name:
options: Because after I become a part of their group, I can become popular too.
Because I would love to learn from someone's good company and good habits.
Because preserving nature and taking action towards it is the right thing to do.
Because they can learn a lot from my gardening skills.

question.questionText: Individuals with a lower status may find themselves readily persuaded by the viewpoints of those with a higher status, primarily due to the following reasons:
options: They hold these individuals in high regard and aspire to emulate their success.
They seek guidance from these accomplished individuals in order to unlock their own potential and pursue growth.
The influence of status is minimal in this context; rather, the focus is on validating the accuracy of one's stance.
Personally, I remain indifferent to an individual's financial standing and do not hesitate to offer corrective feedback when necessary.

question.questionText: The government has set up a color-coded dustbin system to help waste collectors. But it won't work unless we all do our part. When I need to throw away trash outside:
options: I check out what others are doing. If nobody's using the bins, I wonder if it really matters if I follow the rules.
I do my best to use the right bins, but sometimes I might slip up when nobody's watching.
I make sure to put trash in the proper bin, even if it means walking to a trash can or carrying the waste with me until I get home if I can't find one.
There aren't enough bins provided by the government. If I can't find one right away, I don't want to waste my valuable time searching for one.

question.questionText: When someone attempts to talk to me in a library:
options: I don't want to upset them or break the library rules, so I have to find a balance.
I keep my voice low when responding, as they might need some assistance from me.
I gently discourage this behavior since it isn't appropriate.
I usually don't pay attention to people who do this because they're only wasting their time, and I won't let them waste mine.

question.questionText: If I ever find myself in a situation where I have to choose a different direction from the crowd
options: I might feel very afraid and unsure whether I can stay on that path for long.
I would want to double-check if my choice is right, since I believe people generally make wise decisions in life.
If I'm confident that my choice is correct, I will gladly go in that direction, even if I'm by myself.
I will show them that they were mistaken and that they should reconsider their group behavior.

question.questionText: Challenging tasks can be quite puzzling. When several people mention how tough a task I'm about to undertake is
options: I quickly ask if they can assist me with the task before even attempting it myself.
I'm open to giving it a shot, but if help is available along the way, I'm happy to accept it.
I'll figure out the proper approach to complete the task and only seek help from those who are doing it correctly.
I understand they're just afraid, but no task is too difficult for me.

question.questionText: When faced with unclear situations
options: I watch what others do and follow their lead.
I talk to people to understand their views and find a way to solve the problem.
I ask the person involved for more information so I can make the right decision.
I trust my judgment and move forward. If I'm struggling to understand, it's unlikely anyone else can help.

question.questionText: When my work is vital and must be completely precise:
options: I don't feel sure about the outcome until I ask 5-7 coworkers who are doing the same job.
I try my hardest and look at my coworkers' results to get better and be more precise.
I work hard on my job and aim for the right results, even if I need to start over.
I usually feel good about my work being correct, so I'll do it like any other task I have.

question.questionText: When there's a disagreement and I need to choose between two groups (majority vs. minority), I usually pick
options: The majority, since most people agree with them.
The majority, as I trust that people can make wise choices.
The side that's right, whether it's the majority or minority.
The minority, because they've stood up for their beliefs without giving in to pressure.

question.questionText: A few months ago, a friend of mine bought a new car. After that, I noticed many others getting cars even if they had trouble affording them:
options: I'm considering buying a car too, but I can only afford a used one; at least I'll have a car too.
I don't really need a car at the moment, but I want to ask my friends how having a car has made their lives better.
I'll only get a car when I can comfortably afford it, not because of pressure from others.
I can get a car whenever I choose. I won't let other people influence me.

question.questionText: I am a good human being because of the following
options: The community around me embraced and supported my true self.
My loved ones, friends, and coworkers showed me the way through their actions.
The positive habits and decisions I've made.
My own efforts.

question.questionText: If I have a good friend
options: I feel lucky and I'm ready to do my best to help them, showing how much I value our friendship.
I make sure to pay attention to their suggestions so I can make my life better.
I believe this is true because they choose to do what's right and have good habits.
They understand that I bring value to their life and they can learn many things from me.

question.questionText: One of my really good friend is starting their new business. Last week he requested me if I am willing to invest in his new business as he was short of capital. I was startled at his request and immediately denied. Later this week, he came to check if I would like to contribute a small amount as donation:
options: I thought it was an opportunity for me to feel good, so I quickly donated a large sum of money.
I realized they needed help because life isn't always fair for everyone.

Helping with a donation is the smallest thing I can do for him. Even though I didn't feel comfortable with his investment idea, I knew that donating for a good cause was something I could do. So, I decided to give a small gift to show my support.
If this person's actions are like this when the business is just beginning, I'm not sure how long it will last. Whenever they don't have enough money, will they keep asking me for more donations?

question.questionText: While I was just looking around, I noticed a person selling phones. He showed me a mobile phone. I said I didn't want to buy one. But he told me about a special offer with many extras like an exchange deal, screen protector, free earphones, a long warranty, and a TV streaming service for one year
options: Even though I didn't really need a new phone, I bought it because the offer seemed too good to pass up.
I think it's a great deal and I've also heard good things about this phone from friends. I'll exchange it for my old one.
I'm sure this offer is great, but I don't need a new phone at the moment. I'll purchase one when necessary.
I'm familiar with salespeople. They're mostly similar. I won't allow a salesperson to dictate my choice of phone.

question.questionText: When people ask me for help, they usually don't just ask once. It starts with one favor and then becomes a regular thing. In situations like these
options: I don't want to say no because I'm worried it'll make me less liked, and I can't handle that.
I'll likely do what they need because they're asking for assistance since they truly need it.
I'll assess whether their requests are reasonable and fair. I will only focus on the fair requests.
I'll definitely disregard any additional requests. I don't want to provide too much help to anyone. They might lack a sense of independence if they ask for such favors.

question.questionText: I've been searching for insurance when an agent offers me a policy with incredibly low premiums. I agree right away, but when we start putting the policy together, I find out that I need to pay extra for each rider I want to include. This makes the premium jump by around 50% from the original offer. So, what should I do in this situation?
options: Since I have decided to get the insurance from him now, it might be difficult for me to "say no even if I want to".
I'll get the policy this time, but next time, I'll make sure to ask the agent about any hidden fees first.
That's not fair. They should have told me earlier. I'll cancel the policy and find agents who won't mislead me.
I won't buy insurance from an agent who tries to trick me.

question.questionText: I enjoy sharing my life achievements on social media since:
options: Receiving likes and comments from friends and family makes me happy. It shows they appreciate my accomplishments.
Social media is an easy way to keep loved ones informed about my important life events. It's quicker than calling everyone individually.
Sharing updates with everyone at once ensures nobody misses out on the news.
I continue to notice events on my profile from the past. Who shared them with others? I share for my personal memories.

question.questionText: While driving, when I notice a police car behind me
options: I quickly feel the need to move aside and start driving anxiously.
I understand they might be in a hurry to perform their job, so I gladly make room for them.
I continue driving as usual and will clear a path if they ask me to.
It doesn't matter if they're police or someone important. I'll just pay no attention to them.

question.questionText: When I'm online shopping and I notice a flash sale ending soon:
options: I think it's my final opportunity to get items, so I spend a lot of money and regret it afterward.
I look to see if the prices of items on my wishlist are lower. If they are, I'll buy them.
I understand it's just a trick to make me buy things. I know these sales will happen again.
I purchase what I want when I want. I don't let sales decide when I shop.

question.questionText: When someone ignores me for no reason:
options: I usually feel concerned and try my best to fix the issue.
I think they might be facing a difficult situation. I'm here to listen if they want to talk.
I'm sure I haven't done anything wrong to them.
Perhaps they're dealing with their own issues. I give them space, as I don't want to waste my time on others.

question.questionText: A while ago, as I walked through a market, I saw a large group of people watching a man harshly hitting a kid. The reason was that the child had stolen a biscuit pack from his store, which only cost Rs. 5.
options: I wanted to help the kid, but I couldn't act alone while everyone just stood there watching.
The kid's mistake wasn't that bad for such a harsh punishment. The shopkeeper seemed to be using his power to take out his anger.
It's true that the kid needs to learn from this, but it's the police's job, not for us to take the law into our hands.
I stepped in and rescued the kid. It wasn't fair for them to suffer because of a small mistake and having no one to defend them.

question.questionText: When I drive and notice a traffic officer in uniform waving at me at a red light
options: I get nervous and worry about being in trouble even if I didn't break any traffic rules.
I carefully look to see if the officer wants me to stop. Maybe they want to tell me about a flat tire.
I stop my car and park it to the side. If I broke a rule, I need to learn from my mistake.
Traffic officers are just doing their job to keep me safe. Either way, I won't worry too much about it.

question.questionText: Recently, my boss got a promotion and moved to a higher position. I have noticed that now they are telling me what to do without thinking about whether I have enough time for it. What should I do?
options: I might feel more afraid to share my thoughts because of his new role. I'll do my best to follow everything he says.
I will feel stressed and want to know if my coworkers feel the same and how they're handling it.
This seems like an abuse of power and not a good way to treat someone who works for you. I'll see if the company rules let me switch my supervisor.
Bosses like this can try to take away who you are. I'll stand up for myself.

question.questionText: Your manager has given you a set of challenging deadlines at your job. How do you handle the stress?
options: I might just follow all my boss's instructions, even if it means I'll be totally worn out for days on end.
I'll observe how others cope with tight deadlines and adapt my work approach accordingly.
I'll complete as much as I can during my standard work hours and let my boss know I'll tackle the remaining tasks the next day.
I might quit a job that gives me too much stress and doesn't appreciate my talents.

prompt.headingPara: Do you wish to continue or start over?

progressBar.msg1A: Hey! Finish the complete quiz and I will
progressBar.msg1B: back to you with your Report card.
progressBar.msg2A: Great! You have completed more than 25% of the quiz
progressBar.msg3A: Fantastic progress! You're more than 50% done
progressBar.wellcome_75per: Well Done! You have completed more than 75% of the quiz

main.text1: Here are the results of your psychometric test taken on
main.text2:
. The test assessed your personality 
traits, cognitive abilities, and emotional intelligence. The test results provide valuable insights into your 
strengths and areas for development, helping you understand yourself better.

Information_Driven.name: Information Driven
Information_Driven.description: You are an Information driven person. You have a strong desire to go for what you think and believe is right. You tend to feel low social pressure but may feel somewhat  high compliance pressure . You have an inclination to find facts through your own efforts and may even go on to learn if you need clarity on a topic. You may not be affected by what others are doing if you are sure what you are doing is the correct way accomplish a task. You are not intimidated by society and do not regret rejecting someone's idea or even say a NO to favours offered to you if it does not feel right. If you get the right knowledge, you can utilise it very well to become an extremely compliant individual.
qualities:
Strong desire to 
 do what is right

OK to say NO if 
 they feel it is right

Ideal_Normative.name: Ideal Normative
Ideal_Normative.description: You are an Ideal Normative person. You have a strong desire for approval from society. You tend to feel high social pressure and high compliance pressure. You like to follow the path carved out by the society from past several years and hesitate to take a different road. When someone asks you for favours more than once, you have a difficulty saying the word NO even if you get uncomfortable. While you are an ideal citizen and want to be compliant at all costs, you must also be open to seek guidance/ counseling from any available sources rather than considering the society as right [point blank]
qualities:
strong desire for
 approval from society

Difficulty saying NO 
 when others ask you for a favour

Friendly_Follower.name:
Friendly
Follower
Friendly_Follower.description: You are a Friendly Follower person. You have a strong desire to listen, learn and adapt from others because you are flexible and believe that there is always something you can learn from others. You may feel high Social pressure at times but  low compliance pressure. If given a chance, you like to improve yourself by learning from anyone who is willing to offer you the help. When someone asks you for a favour, you have a tendency to help them to make their life better if it is in your capacity. You are not  rigid and quickly learn/adopt better compliance habits.
qualities:
strong desire to 
listen and learn from others

Individualist_Rebellion.name: Individualist Rebellion
Individualist_Rebellion.description: You are an Individualist Rebellion person. You have a very strong desire to stick to your individuality and protect it. You tend to feel low or no social as well as compliance pressure. You have an inclination to never let the majority wipe out your or some minority's point of view or opinion. You are not affected by what society may think of you and sometimes even take a contrarian approach in doing things. While it is okay to protect your individuality, it mmay not hurt so much to follow the someone where can help you be a better compliant person without putting the pressure to do all by yourself.
qualities:
strong desire to 
stick to your individuality

Do not hesitate 
 to say NO

graph.heading: Graph Chart Example
graph.Xaxis_label: Confirmity to Scale of Social Pressure ->

text_content.confirmity: Confirmity is the lowest form of social pressure. Since you are most affected by confirmity social influence, you are sincere and get quickly affected by the social influences around you. You may even feel compelled to do things even if nobody is forcing them upon you.
text_content.compliance: Compliance is a moderate form of social pressure. Since you are most affected by compliance social influence, you are affected by social influences around you. You feel the urge to do things right if possible and can make extra efforts to accomplish tasks even if there is no penalty for the same.
text_content.Obedience: Obedience is the highest form of social pressure. Since you are most affected by obedience social influence, you may not be affected by lighter forms of social influence around you. You may not feel compelled to accomplish work unless it carries a penalty or punishment.
text_content.notObedience: Confirmity is the lowest form of social pressure. Compliance is moderate form of social pressure. A dominant combination of confirmity and compliance implies you are highly influenced by little to moderate social pressure.
text_content.notCompliance: Confirmity is the lowest form of social pressure. Obedience is the highest form of social pressure. A dominant combination of confirmity and obedience is rare but it implies you are either black or white. You may or may not be influenced by little to high social pressure.
text_content.notConfirmity: Compliance is moderate form of social pressure. Obedience is the highest form of social pressure. A dominant combination of compliance and obedience implies you are influenced by moderate to high social pressure.

radialBar.heading: RadialBarChart Example

group_size_or_unanimity?.lessthan_5: Group Size or unanimity can imply that sometimes a large group of people agreeing unanimously can affect the decision of a person if it is otherwise. Your score tells that you are neutral when faced with a large group size and your decision does not get a lot influenced by their unanimous consent. Your score tells that you do not get influenced when faced with a large group size and your decision does not change as per the unanimous consent of the group.
group_size_or_unanimity?.equalto_5: Group Size or unanimity can imply that sometimes a large group of people agreeing unanimously can affect the decision of a person if it is otherwise. Your score tells that you are neutral when faced with a large group size and your decision does not get a lot influenced by their unanimous consent.
group_size_or_unanimity?.morethan_5: Group Size or unanimity can imply that sometimes a large group of people agreeing unanimously can affect the decision of a person if it is otherwise. Your score tells that you get influenced when faced with a large group size and your decision automatically inclines to the unanimous consent of the group.

cohesion_or_status_of_others?.lessthan_5: Cohesion implies when two or more friends, colleagues or just people sitck to a decision and you are yet to decide on yours. Status of a person normally implies a person coming from a standing in society, or powerful in some way or the other. Your score tells that you do not  alter your decisions or options when faced with a situation like this and normally voice your opinion around these people as you would around anyone else.
cohesion_or_status_of_others?.equalto_5: Cohesion implies when two or more friends, colleagues or just people sitck to a decision and you are yet to decide on yours. Status of a person normally implies a person coming from a standing in society, or powerful in some way or the other. Your score tells that you are neutral when faced with a situation like this and your decision does not get influenced by such people around you.
cohesion_or_status_of_others?.morethan_5: Cohesion implies when two or more friends, colleagues or just people sitck to a decision and you are yet to decide on yours. Status of a person normally implies a person coming from a high standing in society, or powerful in some way or the other. Your score tells that you do alter your decisions or options when faced with a situation like this and although you may not like it you will normally not voice your opinion around these people.

Reciprocity?.lessthan_5: Reciprocity can be explained by two techniques of compliance. (i) Door in the face  technique and (ii) That's not all technique. Door in the face technique is where someone comes with a huge request which you are sure to reject. Later the same person comes with a small request which you are bound to oblige because you feel guilty for rejecting one request already. That's Not All Technique refers a technique for gaining compliance in which a requester offers additional benefits to target persons before they have decided whether to comply with or reject specific requests.  Your score tells that you are not influenced when faced with such a situation and you are already aware of the technique of reciprocity.
Reciprocity?.equalto_5: Reciprocity can be explained by two techniques of compliance. (i) Door in the face  technique and (ii) That's not all technique. Door in the face technique is where someone comes with a huge request which you are sure to reject. Later the same person comes with a small request which you are bound to oblige because you feel guilty for rejecting one request already. That's Not All Technique refers a technique for gaining compliance in which a requester offers additional benefits to target persons before they have decided whether to comply with or reject specific requests.  Your score tells that you are neutral when faced with a situation like this and your decision does not get a lot affected by reciprocity.
Reciprocity?.morethan_5: Reciprocity can be explained by two techniques of compliance. (i) Door in the face  technique and (ii) That's not all technique. Door in the face technique is where someone comes with a huge request which you are sure to reject. Later the same person comes with a small request which you are bound to oblige because you feel guilty for rejecting one request already. That's Not All Technique refers a technique for gaining compliance in which a requester offers additional benefits to target persons before they have decided whether to comply with or reject specific requests.  Your score tells that you are influenced when faced with a situation like this and your decision gets affected by reciprocity.

Commitment_and_Consistency?.lessthan_5: Commitment and consistency can be explained by two techniques of compliance. (i) Foot in the door technique and (ii)low ball technique. Foot in the door technique is where someone asks you for a favour and once you fulfil that they will come with another and so on. They have put  a foot in your door and will continue to make you do things until you realise this is a technique of compliance. Low ball technique is where sales people lure you with unbelievable offers first and once you want to buy them, they put extra costs to make it even.  Your score tells that you do not  alter your decisions or options when faced with a situation like this. You already recognise these compliance techniques and do not usually fall prey to them. Only when you feel it to be genuine, you will give in.
Commitment_and_Consistency?.equalto_5: Commitment and consistency can be explained by two techniques of compliance. (i) Foot in the door technique and (ii) low ball technique. Foot in the door technique is where someone asks you for a favour and once you fulfil that they will come with another and so on. They have put  a foot in your door and will continue to make you do things until you realise this is a technique of compliance. Low ball technique is where sales people lure you with unbelievable offers first and once you want to buy them, they put extra costs to make it even. Your score tells that you are neutral when faced with a situation like this and your decisions are not influenced by these compliance techniques.
Commitment_and_Consistency?.morethan_5: Commitment and consistency can be explained by two techniques of compliance. (i) Foot in the door technique and (ii) low ball technique. Foot in the door technique is where someone asks you for a favour and once you fulfil it they will come up with the next one and so on. They have put  a foot in your door and will continue to make you do things until you realise this is never ending. Low ball technique is where often sales people lure you with unbelievable offers first and once you want to buy them, they put extra costs to make it even. Your score tells that you do alter your decisions or options when faced with a situation like this. Start recognising these techniques in your work and make better compliance decisions.

Scarcity?.lessthan_5: Scarcity can be explained by two techniques of compliance. (i) Deadline and (ii) Playing hard to get. (i) Deadline Technique is a technique for increasing compliance in which target persons are told that they have only limited time to take advantage of some offer or to obtain some item. Scarcity plays a chief role in persuading people to buy a certain item. (ii) Playing Hard to Get efforts to increase compliance by suggesting that a person or object is scarce and hard to obtain. Your score tells that you are not influenced by technique of scarcity.
Scarcity?.equalto_5: Scarcity can be explained by two techniques of compliance. (i) Deadline and (ii) Playing hard to get. (i) Deadline Technique is a technique for increasing compliance in which target persons are told that they have only limited time to take advantage of some offer or to obtain some item. Scarcity plays a chief role in persuading people to buy a certain item. (ii) Playing Hard to Get efforts to increase compliance by suggesting that a person or object is scarce and hard to obtain. Your score tells that you are neutral when faced with a situation like this and your decision does not get a lot affected by technique of scarcity.
Scarcity?.morethan_5: Scarcity can be explained by two techniques of compliance. (i) Deadline and (ii) Playing hard to get. (i) Deadline Technique is a technique for increasing compliance in which target persons are told that they have only limited time to take advantage of some offer or to obtain some item. Scarcity plays a chief role in persuading people to buy a certain item. (ii) Playing Hard to Get efforts to increase compliance by suggesting that a person or object is scarce and hard to obtain. Your score tells that you are influenced when faced with a situation like this and your decision gets affected by technique of scarcity.

Authority/_commands?.lessthan_5: Commands from authority figures often carry punishment and (or)  penalty. It forces people to obey or get things done which they will otherwise skip or delay. Your score tells that you are not affected a lot by aquthority or commands. It may be so because you are already rational in your approach and more informationally driven. If you are a friendly follower or Ideal normative, you clearly do not need commands from authority figures to get things done. You are diligent enough to accomplish things.
Authority/_commands?.equalto_5: Commands from authority figures often carry punishment and (or)  penalty. It forces people to obey or get things done which they will otherwise skip or delay. Your score tells that you are neutral when faced with a situation like this and your decision does not get a lot intimidated by such commands from authority figures.
Authority/_commands?.morethan_5: Commands from authority figures often carry punishment and (or)  penalty. It forces people to obey or get things done which they will otherwise skip or delay. Your score tells that you do get affected by authority figure to get things done. In case you are an individualist rebellion, it is so because lighter forms of compliance and confirmity do not have a lot of affect on you in terms of getting things done.

about.UDYAM_UPLIFT_DESCRIPTION: Udyam Uplift is an empirical framework designed as a self assessment test that helps women entrepreneurs (WE) prioritise compliance by leveraging principles of compliance psychology and social influence.
about.UDYAM_UPLIFT_QUESTION_TEST: Udyam Uplift uses a 26-question test to assess an entrepreneur's susceptibility to various compliance traps, including conformity, compliance, and obedience. The test results are used to classify the entrepreneur into one of four quadrants: Ideal Normative, Friendly Follower, Information Driven, or Individualist Rebellion.
about.UDYAM_UPLIFT_DONUT_CHART: Udyam Uplift also provides a donut chart that reveals the percentage of influence from each social pressure factor: conformity, compliance, and obedience. Additionally, Udyam Uplift closely evaluates the entrepreneur's responses to identify which compliance trap techniques they are most susceptible to.
about.UDYAM_UPLIFT_CAN_HELP_ENTREPRENEURS: UDYAM UPLIFT CAN HELP ENTREPRENEURS TO
about.UNDERSTAND_SUSCEPTIBILITY: Understand their susceptibility to various compliance traps
about.IDENTIFY_AREAS_FOR_IMPROVEMENT: Identify areas where they need to improve their compliance posture
about.DEVELOP_STRATEGIES_TO_MITIGATE_RISKS: Develop strategies to mitigate their compliance risks
about.CREATE_COMPLIANT_WORKPLACE_CULTURE: Create a more compliant workplace culture
about.WHAT_IS_COMPLIANCE_TRAP_FOR_WE: WHAT DOES A COMPLIANCE TRAP FOR A WE LOOK LIKE?
about.DEFINITION_OF_COMPLIANCE_TRAP: A compliance trap is a situation in which an individual or organization is incentivized to comply with a rule or regulation, even though doing so may be harmful or unethical. Compliance traps can be created by a variety of factors, such as social pressure, authority, and reciprocity.
about.EXAMPLES_OF_COMPLIANCE_TRAP: In the context of Udyam Uplift, a compliance trap could be something like:
about.EXAMPLE_1_OF_COMPLIANCE_TRAP: WE is pressured by her peers to sign a contract with a supplier who has a history of non-compliance.
about.EXAMPLE_2_OF_COMPLIANCE_TRAP: WE is afraid of being penalized by a regulator if she does not comply with a new regulation, even though she does not understand the regulation or why it is necessary.
about.EXAMPLE_3_OF_COMPLIANCE_TRAP: WE feels obligated to return a favor to a colleague by signing a contract, even though the contract contains terms that are not in her best interests.
about.UDYAM_UPLIFT_FOR_LENDING_ORGANIZATIONS: Udyam Uplift is a valuable tool for lending organizations that are looking to reduce their risk, improve their performance, and build a more compliant business ecosystem Udyam Uplift can help lending organizations to:
about.REDUCE_RISK_OF_DEFAULTS: Reduce the risk of defaults by identifying compliance risks in borrowers.
about.IMPROVE_LOAN_PORTFOLIO_QUALITY: Improve the quality of their loan portfolios by selecting borrowers who are more likely to be successful
about.MAKE_BETTER_LENDING_DECISIONS: Make better lending decisions by providing insights into borrowers' motivation and behavior.
about.ENHANCE_REPUTATION: Enhance their reputation by demonstrating their commitment to compliance.
about.USE_CASE_FOR_UDYAM_UPLIFT_FOR_LENDING_OR: Here is a specific use case of how Udyam Uplift can be used by lending organizations to reduce the risk of defaults:
about.EXAMPLE_OF_DEFAULT_RISK: For example, a borrower who is classified as an 'Individualist Rebellion' may be more likely to ignore or disregard compliance requirements, which could lead to regulatory penalties and disruptions to their business.
about.REDUCE_RISK_AND_MAKE_INFORMED_DECISIONS: Udyam Uplift can help lending organizations to make more informed lending decisions and to reduce the risk of defaults.
about.REDUCTION_IN_DEFAULT_RATE: Reduction in default rate due to Udyan Uplift
about.IMPROVEMENT_IN_LOAN_PORTFOLIO_QUALITY: Improvement in loan portfolio quality due to Udyam Uplift
about.IMPROVEMENT_IN_LENDING_DECISION_MAKING: Improvement in lending decision-making accuracy due to Udyam Uplift
about.UDYAM_UPLIFT_FOR_COMPLIANCE_CHAMPIONS: Udyam Uplift is greatly beneficial, to identify the compliance champions from a community. By identifying and engaging compliance champions, impact consultants can help their clients to create a more culture of compliance within their communities. This can help to reduce the risk of compliance violations and improve the overall social and environmental performance of the community.
about.USE_CASE_FOR_UDYAM_UPLIFT_FOR_IMPACT_CON: Here is a use case of how an impact consultant could use Udyam Uplift to identify and engage compliance champions:
about.TRAINING_FOR_COMPLIANCE_CHAMPIONS: The impact consultant provides training on compliance best practices to the potential compliance champions. The impact consultant also empowers the compliance champions to contribute through knowledge and connectedness that they bring to their communities, ensuring verified information dissemination. By recognizing and rewards compliance champions for their contributions to improving the company's compliance posture.
about.FINANCIAL_IMPACT_OF_UDYAM_UPLIFT: Financial impact of Udyam Uplift on clients
about.CAXPERT_ACCOUNTING_SERVICES: CAxpert offers accounting services, specifically tailored for small businesses, with an emphasis on integrating third-party technologies with accounting programs for safe and smooth data exchange.
about.CAxpert_HANDS_ON_SERVICES: Delivering hands-on services, CAxpert provides a comprehensive solution for accounting and compliance-related concerns as well as basic financial requirements. This allows businesses to focus on expansion without worrying about the intricacies of financial management.
about.SMALL_BUSINESS_OWNERS_ENGINE_OF_GROWTH: Small business owners are the engines of growth for our economy and their books should reflect that too.
